unit_learning_outcomes.description: Articulate the benefits and drawbacks of various theoretical frameworks based on Egyptian and Ancient Near Eastern archaeological and textual data.
Understand theories on the rise and fall of cultural complexity
Know the various factors that led to state formation in a selection of Ancient Near Eastern cultures, including Egypt
Convey an understand of how theory meets reality in a discussion of state formation in Egypt and the Near East

non_scheduled_learning_activities.description: Weekly readings to be completed before coming to class each week.

enrolment_rules.description: 20cp at 2000 level including AHIS280 or AHIS2250 or AHIS261

assessments.description: Short oral presentation (30 min.) on a topic from a list of topic choices
Students must complete the assigned weekly readings and answer a weekly research question. Students will be prepared to discuss their answers to these questions in class.
Produce an annotated bibliography (min. 20 references) from a list of topic choices

data.unit_offering_text:
Session 2, Weekday attendance, North Ryde
Session 2, Fully online/virtual
Session 2, Special circumstances, North Ryde
data.subject_search_title: AHIS3251 - State Formation: Egypt and the Near East
data.description: This unit examines the origin and development of the "state" in Egypt and the ancient Near East through investigation of the archaeological, historical, textual, and artistic evidence. Particular attention is given to the processes involved in the formation of the first states in Egypt and Mesopotamia, as well as secondary states elsewhere in the Near East, in particular Israel. Theoretical models for understanding what a state is and does will form the foundation upon which the actual ancient evidence is overlaid.
data.search_title: AHIS3251 - State Formation: Egypt and the Near East
